New design for Trintcore...

This is a Buffer Tube Cover designed to slip over a standard mil-spec buffer tube of an AR15 airsoft rifle or pistol. This is not a stock, and can not be shouldered. It only acts as a cheek rest, and adds to the aesthetics of your AR or other airsoft variant. If you have a smaller printer, there is a two piece design for you. If you have a large enough printer, there is a single piece design. I also included a "test" piece to see if the cover will fit your AR15 (no need to waste filament if it won't work). For installation:
  • Print out the test piece first to ensure fitment. Then print out your cover, and your pin.
  • If you use the two piece model, it is best to glue them together. Putting them on the buffer tube helps align it while gluing.
  • Placing a small patch of felt velcro on the end of the buffer tube helps with fitting.
  • On the buffer tube, carefully measure out to the center of the last hole. Measure the same distance on the cover, and mark it.
  • Drill out a 1/4" hole on the cover at the mark you made on the under side of the cover.
  • Drop the pin into the hole. You can either glue it in place, or heat up the pin and "solder" it in.
    • NOTE: The installation pin isn't necessary, but helps keep the cover in place. It can be removed again by carefully drilling it out. You may also choose to drill out a hole and use a set screw, instead of the pin, for easier removal. DISCLAIMER: I do not take responsibility for how you choose to use this design. I am uploading it with airsoft guns in mind. I am not responsible for any damage you cause to your gun. This is not a firearm, and can not be converted to fire anything. It is a tubular piece of plastic, with no firing mechanism at all in it. The program I used to design this keeps exporting my models in metric (even though I have chosen inches). Multiply the scale by 25.4 and it should fit. Sorry for the inconvenience.

comments.text: Just FYI for you and others, if this is used on a buffer tube that CAN accept a stock, pretty sure you'd be in murky water with regards to NFA if your barrel is < 16".  The requirements for an AR pistol require a pistol buffer tube that does not have the rail with detentes to accept a stock.  If this were permanently welded, then maybe that would be ok!
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: Its for Airsoft. m8, If some idiot tried to use this on their REAL fire arm its not OP's Fault. Its not designed for REAL STEAL use.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: Not true. You can use a buffer that can accept a stock but the use of a stock is very illegal. What this model does is prevents the unintentional placement of a stock on the buffer tube. As long this model prevents the addition of a stock being attached to the buffer tube, there are no issues with using this model for building an AR pistol. It wouldn't hurt to add some epoxy or something to help adhere it to the tube but as long as the lower was built as a pistol and does not have a stock on the buffer tube with a barrel under 16 inches, there is nothing wrong here.
comments.author: IVIUPPET

comments.text: I understand the concern. I am not responsible for the way people use it, and I do not want anyone breaking the law because of this. If someone does decide to use it for a non airsoft pistol with a buffer tube, then it would need to be permanent, with the pin melted in place or more permanent measures. :)

author: mauroalfieri

description.text: Emilio by emraen [created on 3DTin]

I accidentally burnt out the spindle motor on my mf-70 recently while milling steel (Not v impressed at quality, it stalled, spat out some smoke then died). I had a spare turnigy 2217 860kv 22A motor from my quadcopter, so decided to replace the stock brushed motor with this much nicer brushless one. This part clicks into the spinning body of the motor, and has a hole for the stock rubber coupling. I was thinking I'd immediately mill a metal part for increased strength, but this seems to be fine so far.

Print. clean up with a scalpel (in particular the four nubs on the top were a little blobby for me so didn't initially fit the motor). Insert rubber coupling and place on the spindle. I will mill/3d print a mounting for the motor, although for now I just attached the provided mounting plate and cable-tied it to the mill housing, and used some heatshrink and bolts to loosely hold it in place. This actually works pretty well.

title: Robotic Linkage Toolkit (70pc)- Jansen, Klann, Ghassaei, Chebyshev's Lambda + more included

description.text:
HOW THIS WORKS Linkages provided in cm from extremes of pivot centres for easy calculation.
From 2-0cm to 19.5cm in 0.5 cm increments. (30 pc's) Pivots are 4mm in .stl file though fit nicely with 3/16 inch bolts or 3mm thread. Printed pivot sat at 3.8mm in diametre for me. Includes centre pivot points for circular action. To make lever of 1:3, 1:5 etc, extend two of or more of the same length by matching centre holes with extremes. Also provided is a "wall mount" holding 15 pc's each. Also provided, ready to go linkages for Jansen, Klann, Ghassaei and Chebyshev's Lambda Leg Mechanisms for easy use
These are used for walking robots and leg mechanisms How to use Jansen Linkage (13pc):
Jansen Linkages can be found under "SLJ_Final-Jansen..." file names. Actual size is given next from pivots; "...Jansen_14_9163cm...". Next is the part you will need; "...en_149163cm49" In this case the 49 is the relevant "i" in http://www.mechanicalspider.com/elements/jpegs/TheoJansenLinkage.jpg To put Jansen linkage together print of all linkages and match relevant number after "...cm..." in .stl file name with supplied link. How to Klann Linkage(8pc):
Print off relevant "...Klann..." files. Use relevant sizes as above to match up Klann linkages with link; http://robotronics09.blogspot.com.au/2011/01/klann-mechanism.html e.g 490mm which can be found on link above is the stl file named "...Klann...cm_490" How to Ghassaei Linkage (7pc, repeat prints required):
Find file named "...Ghaessi..." (spelt porly). Use relevant sizes as above to match up Klann linkages with link; https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Ghassaei_Linkage.svg/240px-Ghassaei_Linkage.svg.png for examples see above. Ghassaei files with ".66" in name need to be printed twice and extended How to Chebyshev's Lambda (3pc, needs body+vertical leg):
Print off relevant "...Lambda..." files. Use relevant sizes as above to match up Lambda linkages with link; https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chebyshev%27s_Lambda_Mechanism for examples see above. Legs are long vertical linkages attached the top of Lambda linkages of relative length 2.5 (longest ones).
For body, I will update, I forgot :). for now extend more of length 1? Scale stl file vertically for extra structural integrity. Please rate and comment, I would like to know if I going in the right direction references: Mechanisms and Mechanical Devices Sourcebook, Fiftth edition, Neil Sclater, McGraw Hill 2011 http://www.amandaghassaei.com/files/thesis.pdf https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/Ghassaei_Linkage.svg/240px-Ghassaei_Linkage.svg.png

2.5, 3.5, 4.5...

Blender 3D You can create a linkage quiet quickly by creating a circle, extruding and scaling up. Move off the centre of the grid along the x axis. Grab relevant vertices close to the y-axis or origin and scale to this point (the centre).
Then mirror and extrude vertically.
delete unwanted face along mirrored face.
for centre pivot, move current pivot centre to centre of world origin. Delete all vertices to relevant side of origin, then mirror again.

author: joehuck

description.text:
This is a set of elements to build a charging station for both 12V and USB charging. It consists of three basic elements:
  • Bottom element (bottom_case.stl) for 5 USB chargers (use this one: https://www.banggood.com/DC-7V-24V-To-DC-5V-3A-USB-Output-Converter-Step-Down-Module-KIS3R33S-p-912110.html) and one 12V socket with a switch (use a standard snap-in switch for cars). A standard glass fuse holder is used.
  • Intermediate element (intermediate_case.stl) for 5 USB chargers and one 12V socket, but no switch.
  • Top cover (top_cover.stl)
    They are screwed together using 6 M3 threaded rods and 12 nuts (one on top and bottom for each rod). On top, the nuts are recessed, on bottom the rods stick out (you need some play for mounting) and you can put the little covers (screw_cover.stl) on top of that for better looks and protection from scratching.
    • Due to popular demand (the people being me :p) I now added a set of models for a charging station with no 12V socket, only USB chargers. The concept and the build is the same, they are just narrower due to the socket being cut away. Use the _no_socket models. You can see how it looks as a part of a solar charging station on one of the pictures. I also used this set of connectors to build the station.

Printer:

Craftbot

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

250 um

Infill:

25-33%

Notes: Preferably use a transparent filament to see the lights of the USB chargers.
Supports should be placed in the 12V socket holes, switch hole and under the intermediate segment and optionally in the USB socket holes and fuse holder hole (depending on how good your 3D-printing setup is with bridging).
Flip the top cover and support only the nut recesses.

Assembly Print everything (1 bottom element and cover, 6 screw covers and the preferred number of intermediate elements (each adds 5 USB chargers)), preferably with transparent filament (transparent PLA, PET or polycarbonate) to see the USB charger LEDs. Screw in the USB modules using short 2mm wood screws. The little nub at the USB opening is there to gude the led light to the front of the case (if you use a transparent printing filament). Insert and screw in the 12V socket and the fuse holder. Snap in the switch in the bottom element. Wiring is simple:
  • Connect all the negatives together and route the negative wire through the channel at the back.
  • Connect all the positives in each element together and connect them to the fuse, route the cable from the other end of the each element fuse to the switch and then the main power line back up, parallel to the negative. Look at the pictures for the general idea.
  • Fuse the positive main line separately at the source (unless you use a current-limited source, but even then you could play it safe). Use at least 2.5 mm2 of cable cross-section, if you use a 20A main fuse (do not exceed switch current rating).
    • Take a 1m piece of 3mm threaded rod, stack the wired elements, stick in the threaded rod and snip off the excess length, leaving about 5 mm to make the assembly easier. Screw together, taking care that there is no thread sticking out on top (you can add a drop of superglue in the top nut to prevent it moving on the threaded rod. Add and tighten (gently and cross-wise) the bottom nut and stick the screw cover on the protruding part of the threaded rod. See pictures for the concept. Connect to power source, turn on the switch and marvel at the lovely lights ;) You now have Nx5 USB (and possibly N 12V) charger sockets (N being the number of segments) just waiting to be plugged in!

comments.text: Do you still need the 20A fuses if you're doing the no-socket version?  I noticed you don't have a cutout for them.  Also, what diameter wire do you suggest for 1) coming from the battery and 2) going to each USB board?  Thanks!
comments.author: brossz

comments.text:
ALWAYS put a fuse on your battery, as close to the battery as possible - this is for fire/explosion prevention.
I used a corded fuse holder that I connected directly to the battery pole.
The fuses on the socketed version are for the individual sockets, but you still always need one main fuse at the battery.
If you are going to build the no-socket version, you should be good with a 2,5 mm2 cable going from the battery (with max. 16 A main fuse), but you can use thinner cables to individual USB boards - I used a separate 0,75 mm2 cable to each individual board. It would be hard to connect thicker cables anyway. You then have to bundle the thinner cables and connect them to the thicker one in one place.

remixed_from.title: Diamond Hotend for RostockMAX + TrickLaser effector platform

title: Diamond magnetic effector for delta Kossel or Rostock
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: I made a plate to work with Renha's Diamond hotend for Rostock. I have included Renha's part here, unaltered. Renha's part required an aluminium plate and it works with ball joint connectors. I have made a plate that can be printed and works along with Renha's part and also uses Haydn Huntley's magnetic ball joint end rod assemblies. Haydn sells his custom made steel ball mounts and provides the files for you to print your own assemblies or he offers them made to order. I highly recommend his stuff and you can see his work here: https://www.youmagine.com/users/haydn-huntley Note, I had to use MeshMixer to do a "Plane Cut" about 3/4 of an inch up from the bottom of Renha's part in order to make room for the Diamond print head to stick out far enough. Not sure why I had to do this, but it worked perfectly. If you need the magnetic ball carriage part to go along with this, please see my thingiverse carriage part here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:719276
This effector plate was made with 123D Design by Autodesk.  I have included the 123D files in case you need to tweak anything.

comments.text:
How did you intend mounting the two pieces together?
The holes in the effector plate that line up with the diamond holder "legs" appear to be clearance for M4. The holes in the legs of the holder appear to be clearance (or nearly so) for M3. The legs don't appear to have enough thickness to allow tapping them for M4 fasteners.
Thanks.
Frederick
comments.author: fcwilt

comments.text: I used american fastener sizes instead of metric.  I don't remember exactly what size is slightly larger than M3, but that is what I used.  In some cases like these I might put a drop of super glue in the hole and a light spray of cooking oil on the bolt.  Screw it in and let the glue harden for instant smaller threads.  The cooking spray prevents the glue from bonding to the bolt.
comments.author: fcwilt

comments.text:
Not metric - interesting - I have a large assortment of metric fasteners but not much in imperial. I'll give the glue/oil approach a try. Now that the design program you used is no longer available can you post the design files in some format that Fusion 360 can open - that program seems to be the "replacement" for 123D.
I would like to make the changes that we have discussed - shortening the legs and metric fasteners.
Thanks.
Frederick
comments.author: Olooki3D

comments.text:
The diamond holder you are asking about was not made by me. I simply made the effector plate that attaches to it. As described in my description of the file, I had to cut off about 3/4 inch to get my diamond nozzle to stick out below the plate. I just uploaded my version of that shortened plate. it is called DiamondMagEffectorFanShroud_fixed. I wish I could upload the file in another format but all I had to work with was the original STL file in the first place.
Hope this helps.
comments.author: fcwilt

comments.text:
Thanks for the information.
If I understand you it was possible to edit the original STL file in some way? I did not know that STL could be edited. Interesting.
Anyway regards the holes in your effector plate - I would like to be able to print a version made for metric fasteners. So can you post that file in any other editable format for some modeling program now that 123D is gone?
Frederick
comments.author: Olooki3D

comments.text: Once a file is in STL format it can be edited not as a CAD object but as a mesh object.  It cannot be easily converted into another file type.  The expensive programs like SolidWorks have method to convert STL to other file types.  There might be some free online converters if you Google it.  I haven't checked.   I was able to use the now abandoned 123D  Design to edit the STL.  I don't know how to do that with any other programs other than maybe meshmixer but it is not a easy to use.  TinkerCAD is basically the same as 123D Design, so you might try that on as well.  I created the effector plate with just over 4mm holes so they should work.  The ball stud holes should work with Hadley's studs ok as well.  The diamond holder part was not designed by me. I just did a quick Google search and it looks like you can import 123D create files into Fusion360.  Last I remember you can get Fusion360 for free and it is very powerful.
comments.author: fcwilt

comments.text: Thanks much for the info.
comments.author: Olooki3D

comments.text: I tried to post some of my questions but they are held up for "moderation" - whatever that is exactly.
comments.author: fcwilt

comments.text: I guess either my heat sinks are longer than the standard one or my heat break tubes are longer.  In either case I would think that one could simply cut enough off of the end of the 3 legs so that when they are mated up with  the effector plate that the tip of the diamond Head will protrude below the plate.  Someone else asked if you need to loosen all 3 heatsinks, insert them into the holder and then tighten each heatsinks down a little bit each until all are tight... Yes, that is the way I had to do it as well.  Then use zip ties to clench the heat sinks to the holder.  Lastly screw the effector plate on.  The diamond tip extends about 1 cm below the effector plate.  Hope this helps.
comments.author: fcwilt

comments.text: Thanks for the info.
comments.author: Olooki3D

comments.text: Fwi, mine is a clone too.  I think the dimensions are the same as the original.

description.text: Inspired by http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:11500 I give you "Me Gusta". Use this face when you want to show the world you like something weird and funny. It's simply two .dxf files put together in openscad. The supplied .stl file is ~7cm in diameter. Source files are supplied, so you should be able to tweak it to your liking. 3) Take photo
4) Upload to thingiverse

remixed_from.author: monnerby
remixed_from.title: InMoov hand dual track servo pulleys

title: InMoov dual track servo pulleys reworked to use servo wheel

description.text:
I was having a problem with the pulleys eventually coming free from the servos so I've used Gaels idea from his later pulleys to incorporate a servo wheel into the pulley to get a more secure grip.
I've also remixed Mats pulley to use the tighter fit from Gael's earlier design because I only had four servo wheels.
I use all four screws that come with the servo to connect the top and bottom pieces together with the wheel sandwiched in between. Two of these screws can then be used to tension the tendon lines.

description.text: This is a beta model of the new M Prime One 3D printed extruder. It is designed to improve the reliability of the previous model. This model is backwards compatible with the current M Prime One frame, although it already includes mounting holes for the next version. You'll have no problem using it in both the current and the future version of the M Prime One frame. This model is interchangeable with the all metal PTSOne extruder. Inspired by the Recreus Extruder (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:263133) and the PTSone Extruder by Printhatshit. Designed from scratch with FreeCAD.
This is a 3D Printer extruder designed to be compatible with the M Prime One 3D printer (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1058861)

title: Raceway Targets Set 01 - LIttle Old Lady, Froggie, Spooky Cat, Chicken, and Slow Children

description.text:
It has been a passion of mine for a long time (about a week) to create "Raceway Targets" that can be run over for World Maker Faire 2011. Perhaps to gain points, perhaps to lose points, perhaps just to be ridiculous. 
Thankfully, Andrew Plumb built an OpenScad project for the brace and the hinged mounting point that makes these possible.
So now it is time for you to create your own 2D designs to be used to make Raceway Targets of your own! Please share your own images or sets! Or your flat items that you would like attached to a hinge and run over!

There are at least three ways to use these:
  • Bring these into OpenSCAD to create cutouts of the flap for a negative silhouette.
  • Bring into OpenSCAD to create positive silhouettes with a hinged base.
  • Print these out on cards and attached to the card-holder hinged piece.
  • Extrude these 2D files into big silhouettes that you glue to the blank hinged piece. (Try contrasting colors!)
    • Now here is how to use 'em!
  • Fix the brace to the ground.
  • Flip the hinged character silhouette up so that it is visible on the road.
  • Run over the character!
  • Flip the hinged character back up!
    • You might want to download QCAD to open the DXF files and explode them before export -- makes OpenSCAD much happier.

author: Auero

description.text: A simple one piece stand that can be used for holding printed recipes up to 8.5" X 11" in sheet size.  This was designed specifically to work with the recipe cards that Blue Apron provides in their meal kits and is a great way to free up counter space.  The Blue Apron recipe cards are printed on heavier card stock than regular computer paper.  It does not work well on light weight paper like computer paper if you are using a full size sheet.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

200 Micron

Infill:

5%

Notes: Design has generous corners and does not require rafts. Actual resolution or infill % does not matter. Do not scale the design if you expect it to work. To deal with the tolerance required to hold a sheet of paper I simply just made the slot curved.
Part is modeled in geomagic design. Slot is curved to give sheet stiffness and to allow for grasping of recipe card.  Slot is angled to ease viewing.

Grado headphones are awesome, but the foamy ear pads dissolve way to fast.  So I decided to try to make some out of NinjaFlex rubber filament.  The fit is perfect on my circa. 1994 SR80s.  Not sure how the can size has changed over the years, but they look to be pretty similar shapes.
The comfort of this design is not as good as original foam, but I expect tuning of build parameters could help soften them up.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2X

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.16

Infill:

10%, but experiment!

Notes: This was printed in NinjaFlex, 4 layer top/bottom, 3 layer walls, 10% infill. These settings make it very robust, but it's still a bit firm. I'd recommend trying 2 layer walls, and maybe down to 8% infill. Keep at least 2 layer spacing on top side of the support or it's really hard to put out. NinjaFlex is super strong. The pair took a good 8 hours to print on the speed settings I use for NinjaFlex.
Easy print if you got NinjaFlex already running Supports can be a bit challenging to get out. So leave at least 0.5mm horizontal space on supports, and 2 layer gap on top / bottom contact surfaces.
Autotdesk Inventor Got out the callipers and modelled it up in about 15 minutes. Simple sketch and revolve.

Nut joiner for threaded hole in the knob;
Bolt 25x8 printed seperately;
Washer 1x8.5 printed seperately.

description.text:
!UPDATE: V2.1 has a bit more forward angle so the spool doesn`t unbalance the printer.!
The insertion method for the bracket underneath has been updated as well.

Probably the easiest way to make a filament holder for 1Kg rolls on your M3D printer.
It only requires one printed part (which can be printed on an M3D) and a paint roller set which you can get at any hardware store.
The printed part is designed for paint rollers with an 8mm round metal roller bracket. There is a small roll holder now available as well:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1160306

Instructions:
  • Print the .stl file
  • Remove the plastic handle from the paint roller.
    I used a hacksaw to cut it in halves.
  • Wait for the printer....
  • Wait for the printer....
  • Remove the part from the printer and remove the support material from the hole.
  • Hold the metal bracket with some pliers and heat the bracket for a minute.
    then insert it into the holder, it will melt itself in.
    Make sure it is inserted properly and straight.
    Don't move it while it cools down, DONE!
    !!BE AWARE OF THE HEAT, DON'T BURN YOURSELF!!
    • Happy printing!

Printer:

M3D

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

Medium quality

Infill:

High or Full infill setting in the M3D software

Notes: The full infill option in the M3D software matches 50% infill on regular printers.
The inside will be build up out of a square mesh.
I used the Full option in the M3D menu with succes. Printed mine in PLA but ABS will probably work as well.

title: MOTU - Castle Grayskull elevator rail replacement part

description.text:
Replacement part.Orange elevator rail for the playset from "Masters of the Universe - Castle Grayskull" 1980's.
Printed, tested and confirmed. I left out the hole in the rail for the string. I usually just drill my prints afterwards. Just superglue the rails together. Before you glue the pegs to the rails, install it in the castle so everything lines up. then put some superglue on the pegs and snap in the rail. Also the pegs are gonna need some light sanding just to make a supertight fit.
The original design is flawed, putting too much stress in the rail when pulling the string which I assume is the reason mine broke. So I would advise to either hold a finger above the rail which you let the string slide over or a more permanent solution: Secure a hook in the castle roof or drill a hole in the roof. Haven't decided what I'm gonna do.

comments.text: I've printed this out and I've had trouble with the peg that holds the rail. When I tried to plug it in to the castle the spot is a hexagon shape and doesn't fit. Is your castle have round spots? I'm trying to rework it to fit.http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1787832
comments.author: Megoman

comments.text: I checked and you are correct. The holes are in fact octagonal, but the original rail has cylindrical pegs too so it should fit tightly as the measurements are the same. Mine does. It might be an issue with the printer resolution not producing such smooth and exact shapes. No big deal as sanding would take care of that. Does your modification work better? I can send you the original file instead. Might be easier to tweak.

comments.author: BrennanMacaig

comments.text:
I will try to get a picture of it. But here's the jist of it:
On the switch, there a two different switched circuits which are top and bottom of you are looking at it with the rocker moving left-right. You only need to connect the live terminal from the socket to one end of the switch, then the live wire to the equipment to the corresponding other end of the switch. Then connect neutral and earth to the terminals marked N and E on the socket. Alternatively, you can use the other side of the switch to also switch the Neutral, but it is normally unnecessary.

title: 3in1 Extruder Upgrade

description.text:
This complete extruder feeder upgrade is now available for order. It is manufactured from billet aluminum and PEEK engineering polymer for long life and durability under extreme temperature (PEEK performs well up to 480*F so it will continue to work if you choose to print ABS which requires higher temperature). It has several features which correct some of the short comings of the stock Replicator 2: 1) It employs a bearing to provide even force to the filament as it varies in thickness. This force is easily adjustable without the need to replace parts or disassemble anything. 2) It re-positions the stepper motor rearward so that the gripper wheel can engage the flat on the motor shaft. No more need to file the shaft yourself possibly damaging the stepper motor with metal filings in the bearing. 3) It allows easy access for visual inspection as well as tool access in case of a jam which might require scissors to remove the filament. 4) It also possible to release the bearing pressure easily and quickly to allow filament changes mid-print. This upgrade began development 2 months ago. You can see the development of this design in this discussion:
https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/makerbot/m2X36BIqEWE Since then, it has logged over 600 hours in use combined between 2 printers. This upgrade can be ordered here:
https://docs.google.com/forms/d/16H2nT20j-zPLR_jo6uGLaQNPG6RWTJgjyEGToYtuIG8/viewform The instructions can be downloaded above. Here are some videos showing the upgrade in action (while still in the prototype stage). Prototype Extruder Install:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=9miwEBzYHlI Filament Load & Unload Process:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=g9DK7FC_TjU How easy it is to swap filament mid-print:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=q_rd1E05l4Q Read more about it here:
http://3dhacker.com/category/517/MakerBot-Replicator%28s%29/listings/296/3in1-Extruder-Upgrade-Replicator-2.html Happy printing!

Go here to download/order the new improved version:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:136423

author: DHeadrick

title: The Claw - A clamping style filament spool holder

description.text:
Instructions: -BOM- 4 x 626 ball bearings
2 x 10 cm. expanding springs
A handfull of M3 nuts, bolts and shims
-Printed Parts- The number prefixes on the Thing files does not get you what is shown in the pictures... For that, you need to print: 2 x Body (print them standing up, to not worry about overhangs) 2 x Quickrelease (Some nasty overhang/bridge in this one... I printed it without support with a well working crossflow-fan setup, but use support if you have problems) 2 x Holder (Just to get the same distance from the backside of the printer as you will have for the pulleys sitting on the quick releasens 4 x Pulley (print them lying down... they have in-built support which is easily removed with eg. a pair of pliers - EDIT: They also seem to be off scale... They need to hold a 608zz bearing inside, outer diameter should be 34.5mm which equates to a 0.4 scale on all axis) 4 x Skive (These are just to hold the bearings in place, you can use shims as well...optionally you can print two extra to get a little clearance on the backside of the lower pulleys) 2 x Tensioner (Optional - I didn't print them, but just fastned the springs with M3 bolts, shims and nuts through the hole in the bottom of the body) I also printed 2 tube inserts for the bearings in the low placed pulleys to fit with M3 bolts... These are not featured in Thing files as I already had them lying around, but you can easily make your own, they are just 5mm. heigh tubes with an inner diameter of 3 mm and an outer diameter of 8 mm... Once you have everything printet, its pretty self explanatory to assemble and mount (There are screw holes for everything which will basically tell you where stuff goes) When drilling holes in the back of your printer and mounting the parts, its a good idea to use a spool of the size you normally use, to line up the holes and parts nicely with a good distance to each other...
You want some tension in the springs when clamping on the spool, but the quick release shouldn't slide all the way out of the body to make room for the spool (mine is right on the edge, as you can see in the pictures... this allows me to use some smaller spools as well, and still have tension in the springs)
we did it Tommyph1208 and I made a new spoolholder

I don't know if this is a common problem but recently the X axis idler on my Replicator 2x wiggled and pulled itself from the very poorly designed carriage. On top of that the plastic bearing on the steel rod made some of the most annoying noises I've ever heard. I designed this piece to incorporate a metal Idler with a bearing as well as a more secure method of holding the bearing and rod assembly in place on the carriage. I've test fit the part on my replicator 2x but nothing else, I would assume it works on the clones but cant confirm. I replaced the 4mm rod with a 3mm rod to use this idler:
http://www.ebay.com/itm/3D-Printer-Idler-Pulley-Aluminum-Dual-Ball-Bearing-3mm-Bore-16-Teeth-GT2-Belt-/262072280224?hash=item3d04b9a4a0:g:LzEAAOSwKIpWC8yI
3mm rod can be source anywhere. I cut mine longer than the factory rod as it was really loose which I think also lent itself to the issue of it popping out of place. If you have any problems let me know and hopefully we can figure out a solution. Thus far I've logged about 150hrs of print time and not only is it silent but the X belt is staying tight.

Printer:

Prusa i3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

40%

Notes: Nothing special, printed at 100% scale, just had to go through and clean out the holes for the shaft a little to get a good fit.

comments.text: No issues at all.  Has been working great since I installed it and logged at least 2500 hours of use.

  • 6x 10-32 x 1.5" socket cap screws
  • 6x 10-32 jam nuts
  • 3x 1.75 fender washers, 1/4" hole
    • Laser Support keeps jack screws vertical and allows adjustment up and down. Table supports with washers keep the table flat and well supported.

license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Skeinforge didn't like the original gears and I was having trouble getting them to print completely solid resulting in fragile gears that break easily.  So I split them up into separate STLs, repaired the normals, and fixed a few geometry problems using NetFabb.  Now you should be able to print them with 0 extra shells and a high infill for nice strong gears.

author: LylaJT

title: XZ Carriage mod for P3steel V1.0

description.text: This is a modification of the extruder carriage supports for use "protein" trapezoidal Tr8 axis 8 (ext) x 4 (int) x 2 (pitch) and bearings for the shaft end Z KFL08 and LM8LUU Motor-X and X-Idler supports P3steel or Prusa i3 with 17 mm between centers. It can be used two LM8UU or one LM8LUU (Much Better). The bearing've fastened with rivets thermal (melt in position to fix them). I will test one and two TR8 nuts for clearances to eliminate the few that have, even if the nuts that will wear with use and require little filming. Pleaser comment, these design are in constantly develop. New version: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1405962

Este es una modificación pats los soportes del carro del extrusor para usar las "proteinas" del eje trapezoidal Tr8 (ext) x 4 (int) x 2 (pitch) y unos rodamientos para el final del eje Z KFL08. X-Motor y X-Idler es compatible con la Prusa y la P3steel de 17 mm entre ejes. Se pueden usa tanto dos LM8UU como un LM8LUU. El rodamiento lo he sujetado con remaches termicos, (se funden en posición para fijarlos). Haré pruebas con una y dos tuercas por para eliminar las pocas holguras que tengan, aunque las tuercas si que tendrán desgaste con el uso y requieren un pequeño rodaje. Comentar, por favor, son diseños en constante mejora. Nueva versión: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1405962 Video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=me3WLBjeyMk

Printer Brand:

RepRap

Printer:

Prusa P3teel

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 in prototype

Infill:

20 for prototype
Adjusting the asembly Drill axis and clean edges. The bearing mount has to be adjust a little with a rounded sand nut no more than 1mm. very easy. Rhat makes perfect 17 mm between axis
Escariar los ejes y eliminar rebabas. El soporte del rodamiento hay que limarlo un poco com una lija redonda o una lima, pero no mas de 1mm. Es muy fácil. Eso mantiene los 17 mm entre ejes.

Designed in Madrid :-) with Solid Edge ST8 Educational My original M5 threaded rods give me some problems few months of using the printer.
They were very soft and bent at the first snag the z axis. (Who has not happened). I bought some mechanical parts and started to design the new parts based on the idea of Josef Prusa. The idea were raise the quality of the most critical parts as I understand of the prusa's printer. components. I can upload the Parasolid if anyone is interested to develop the idea. Comment, please, and help me to get a better design. Ideas fron josef prusa i3 and kitprinter3d parts https://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3

A mi las varillas roscadas originales me han dado problemas a los pocos meses de uso de la impresora. Eran muy blandas y se doblaban al primer enganchon del eje z. (A quien no le ha pasado). Compré unas cuantas piezas y me puse a diseñar las nuevas piezas partiendo de la idea de prusa. La idea es elevar la calidad de los componentes mas criticos a mi entender de las prusas. Puedo colgar el parasolid si a alguien le interesa para desarrollar la idea. Comentar, por favor y ayudarme a conseguir un mejor diseño. Basado en las piezas de la prusa i3 de josef y las de kitprinter3d https://github.com/josefprusa/Prusa3 P3steel Z axis mod

comments.text: Los remaches térmicos es lo mas sencillo del mundo, me usan en muchos ámbitos desde automoción hasta productos de consumo. Lo mas sencillo es montarlos con presión, si se han impreso bien, ajustarán, pero se quedarán firmes y luego o bien con un soplete muy muy pequeñito, como el de los soldadores de gas, o si no, con un mechero, le vas dando calor y cuando ya esté fundente, lo aplastas contra una superficie fría. comments.author: josemivaz

comments.text: I'm not sure what you mean by patter, but I use regular plaster filler (the one used to cover holes in walls), sanded lightly and then painted to simulate the stucco walls of the lighthouse. The plaster is cheap and can be obtained in any hardware store, there are two versions a light and a heavy compound. I've used both with good results.
comments.author: lordzer

comments.text: Thank you for the info, this will be one the project I'll be doing during the Christmas break.
comments.author: skylab1

comments.text: Are the 12V automotive light LED too, which one did you use?
comments.author: skylab1

comments.text:
Yes, it's a regular 12V replacement LED rear/stop bulb you can find in any auto-parts shop. I included a photo of the bulb in the files section. The lighthouse model has the proper rectangular shape to atach the bulb. Just solder a pair of wires from the terminals of the bulb to the Main LED output of the circuit. Be careful to observe the polarity of the connections.
For the internal lighting, use regular 5mm high intensity LEDs (one or more depending on how much light you want) connected to the LED 1 part of the circuit, remember to calculate the resistor (or resistors) value.
comments.author: skylab1

comments.text: Can you share where did you get the electric circuit for the lights.
comments.author: skylab1

comments.text:
Forgot to tell you that if you are not interested in building the circuit by yourself, there is a company called Bakatronics that I think sells something similar.
Watch the video: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=77GAiAuQ12g
comments.author: skylab1

comments.text:
Hi skylab1, I'm glad you are interested in the electronics.
It is a very simple circuit with few components. The core is the PIC16F628A programmed to generate PWM (pulse wide modulation) on pin RB3, the modulated pulse is feed to a transistor to power the main beam (an automotive 12V light) that can be white, yellow or red. The rest of the circuit is a 5V regulator for the PIC and a resistor to limit current for the inner light LED.
I included the circuit diagram, the componentes layout and the C program for the PIC.
comments.author: skylab1

title: Prusa i3 Rework - X Motor Mount with Magnet Holder for Hall Endstop

description.text: Added a small holder for a magnet for a hall endstop. I'm using the endstop bracket here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:145941 The SCAD files are at my fork at https://github.com/garyjohnson/Prusa3 Just superglue the magnet in and you're good to go!
